messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] book identification
messages.msgSnippet: David, I don t think that the depressions depict anything.  In that style of guard, the hammering and the inlay generally have no apparent relationship.  That
messages.messageBody:
David,
I don't think that the depressions depict anything. In that style of guard, the hammering and the inlay generally have no apparent relationship. That particular one is more coordinated that most.

Jim



Thanks, Jim. That explains why I couldn't find it. I don't own that particular book. Am I correct in thinking the depressions are supposed to be deer tracks?

David Zincavage

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] book identification
messages.msgSnippet: It s from Tsuba Nyumon by Shibata Mitsuo. That type of guard is a fairly common subset of Heianjo-zogan.  The deeply worked plate with inlay running over the
messages.messageBody:
It's from Tsuba Nyumon by Shibata Mitsuo.

That type of guard is a fairly common subset of Heianjo-zogan. The deeply worked plate with inlay running over the concavities, the style of inlay and the shape of the kogai-ana are the distinctive features. Yoshiro is an unusual attribution.

Jim



Does anyone recognize the book this photo comes from? The format is very similar to Tsuba no Bi, but it's not in my copy.



http://zincavage.org/Unknownbook.html

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.msgSnippet: Thanks, Jim.  That explains why I couldn t find it.  I don t own that particular book.  Am I correct in thinking the depressions are supposed to be deer
messages.messageBody:
Thanks, Jim. That explains why I couldn't find it. I don't own that particular book. Am I correct in thinking the depressions are supposed to be deer tracks?

David Zincavage
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, July 22, 2005 3:18 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] book identification


It's from Tsuba Nyumon by Shibata Mitsuo.

That type of guard is a fairly common subset of Heianjo-zogan. The deeply worked plate with inlay running over the concavities, the style of inlay and the shape of the kogai-ana are the distinctive features. Yoshiro is an unusual attribution.

Jim



Does anyone recognize the book this photo comes from? The format is very similar to Tsuba no Bi, but it's not in my copy.



http://zincavage.org/Unknownbook.html

ikkanshi@... writes:

Is the
split bamboo a family emblem ?, it looks familiar. I don't know the

it looks familiar because I have an almost identical one ( pics I sent to
you last year ). I think they are axe and split bamboo, not mon.

milt

messages.subject: one more tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: He is one I picked up tonight. I assume these are both Kakumon ?, Is the split bamboo a family emblem ?, it looks familiar. I don t know the other mon. 85 x 80
messages.messageBody:
He is one I picked up tonight. I assume these are both Kakumon ?, Is the
split bamboo a family emblem ?, it looks familiar. I don't know the
other mon.

85 x 80 x 6mm

Looks mid Edo Akasaka to me, thoughts ?

Rich

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] book identification
messages.msgSnippet: That s not much to go on. The only information there relates to the tsuba and not what the book is. Also, I think your tsuba has the remnants of a melted
messages.messageBody:
That's not much to go on. The only information there relates to the tsuba
and not what the book is. Also, I think your tsuba has the remnants of a
melted design. It looks like it was burnt.

Gordon
